title: 08 Math Instruction In PEI
summary: This February 2021 paper addresses fragmentation in PEI mathematics education, building on the 2013 Community Foundation youth survey identifying educational deficiencies. Don analyzes multiple math providers (public schools, postsecondary institutions, SkillsPEI, private schools, independent learners) operating without coordination or shared definitions. He argues that transition from secondary to post-secondary education depends on mathematics preparation. The paper recommends adopting competency-based outcomes, implementing universal curriculum platforms, independent assessment bodies, and user-based advisory committees. Don's analysis identifies fundamental problems: lack of agreed definitions, no coordination mechanism, inconsistent evaluation criteria, and fragmented delivery. The document reflects his systematic approach to identifying systemic barriers to educational quality.

title: YIP- Speaking notes - Montague
summary: Speaking notes from January 26, 2012 Montague Rotary Club presentation on CFPEI's Youth in Philanthropy (YIP) initiative by Don Glendenning. Outlines CFPEI background (established 1993, improving quality of life, 171 Canadian community foundations), examples of endowments and grants, and YIP program targeting youth aged 15-18. YIP youth councils self-select, meet monthly, assess community needs especially for youth, make grant decisions, and establish endowments. Annual costs are $2,500 per YIP site with $1,000 direct community distribution and $500 endowment challenge. Presentation invites Rotarians to sponsor YIP expansion.

title: YIP- Speaking notes - Susmmerside
summary: Speaking notes from September 20, 2011 Summerside Rotary Club presentation introducing YIP program. Recognizes former directors Paul Schurman, Mary Wilcox, Dave Anderson. Details CFPEI directors including John Robinson, Tom Davies, Rod Nicholson, Stanley Macdonald, Jim Travers, Steve McQuaid, Rogers Bell, Tracey Laughlin, Andrew Daggett, Carol Fraser, Joyce Gaudet. Reports approximately $70,000 annual grants (exceeding $1,000,000 cumulatively since inception), specific scholarships and grants to regional institutions. Describes YIP youth councils as school-based clubs meeting monthly to assess local youth needs and allocate grants. Seeks Summerside Rotary sponsorship for YIP expansion to the area.

title: YIP- Speaking notes
summary: General speaking notes on Youth in Philanthropy program (undated, likely 2010-2011). Outlines CFPEI background (established 1993, 171 Canadian chapters), mission to build endowments and make grants allowing charitable legacy preservation. Identifies needs including finding/retaining trustees and addressing youth volunteerism gaps. YIP focuses on local communities with youth aged 15-18, typically school-based. Youth Advisory Councils self-select, meet monthly, identify youth needs, receive guidance and funds, expected to establish endowments. Benefits include community learning, leadership development, parliamentary procedure, proposal review/assessment skills. Startup costs $2,500 increasing to $3,000-$4,000 by year three per YAC.
